div.p: Located within BIOGRAPHY EDUCATION , this tag records texts significant in educational development, early reading matter which exerted a formative influence, rather than even major influences on her writing, if encountered in maturity.Such texts will probably not be entered here but within her Writing document. Encloses generally just a title or author name, but can enclose a phrase, e.g Greek myth and legend, or German fairy tales.

This has one optional attribute, REG which allows you to standardize the name of the author or title of the book (either of which might be tagged as TEXT) in cases where you have been unable to do in the prose. Used for expanding or fully identifying either Name or Title: <TEXT REG="Eliot, George‚Äù>Eliot</TEXT>, <TEXT REG="The Mill on the Floss">Maggie Tulliver</TEXT> <div>

div.codeblock: <TEXT><TITLE TITLETYPE="Monographic">Old Testament</TITLE></TEXT> and <TEXT><TITLE TITLETYPE="Monographic">Paradise Lost</TITLE></TEXT> by the age of six.

div.p: Title tag is mandatory around texts.

It is fine to tag commonly recognized names like Skakespeare or Milton as texts as well as names within the education element, but only do so if reading such an author carried real significance for the BWW.
Question: Should Jane Eyre be entered as a text within Jean Rhys' BIOGRAPHY because Wide Sargasso Sea is a rewriting of it?
Answer: No. Jane Eyre will be tagged as INTERTEXTUALITY in WRITING.
